skill.name: prpm-json-best-practices
skill.description: Best practices for structuring prpm.json package manifests with required fields, tags, organization, multi-package management, enhanced file format, eager/lazy activation, and conversion hints
skill.summary: Best practices for structuring prpm.json package manifests with required fields, tags, organization,...
skill.author: AgentWorkforce

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code, no file system access, no network calls, and no external command execution. Contains only markdown guidance and JSON schema examples for creating valid prpm.json manifests.

content.value_statement: Creating prpm.json manifests for package publishing requires correct fields, proper organization, and valid JSON structure. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on required fields, multi-package management, collections, tags, and validation for successful package publishing to the PRPM registry.
actual_capabilities: Create valid single and multi-package prpm.json manifests
Configure required fields including name, version, description, format, subtype, and files
Organize packages by privacy, format, and subtype for maintainability
Set up eager or lazy activation for skills and agents
Create collections that bundle multiple packages for easier installation
Validate manifests and verify all referenced files exist
limitations: Does not publish packages to the registry (users run prpm publish manually)
Does not execute scripts or build commands in the manifest
Does not manage prpm.lock or installed dependencies
Does not convert packages between different AI tool formats

use_cases.title: Publish new package
use_cases.description: Create a complete prpm.json for a new skill, agent, or rule to publish to the PRPM registry

use_cases.title: Multi-package repository
use_cases.description: Organize and publish multiple related packages from a single repository with proper metadata

use_cases.title: Bundle packages
use_cases.description: Create curated collections that group multiple packages together for easier discovery and installation

prompt_templates.title: Basic manifest
prompt_templates.scenario: Create prpm.json for a new skill
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a prpm.json for a Claude Code skill named my-skill with description, author, license, and files

prompt_templates.title: Multi-package
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a prpm.json with packages array for a repository containing both Claude skills and Cursor rules

prompt_templates.title: Collection
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a prpm.json with collections array that groups three related packages into a curated setup

prompt_templates.title: Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this prpm.json for missing required fields, duplicate names, invalid file paths, and tag formatting issues

output_examples.input: Create a prpm.json for a TypeScript rule package
output: Required fields set: name, version, description, author, license, format, subtype, files
File path: .cursor/rules/typescript.mdc (verified relative to project root)

best_practices: Always include all required fields: name, version, description, format, subtype, files, author, and license
Use full relative paths from project root for files (e.g., .claude/skills/name/SKILL.md, not agents/name.md)
Group packages by privacy first, then format, then subtype for maintainable organization
anti_patterns: Using relative paths without directory prefix (agents/my-agent.md instead of .claude/agents/my-agent.md)
Mixing installed packages from prpm.lock with packages to publish in prpm.json
Using incorrect tag casing (TypeScript instead of typescript) or format (snake_case instead of kebab-case)

faq.question: What formats does prpm.json support?
faq.answer: Supported formats include claude, cursor, continue, windsurf, copilot, kiro, agents.md, mcp, and generic.

faq.question: What is the difference between packages and collections?
faq.answer: Packages define files to publish. Collections bundle existing packages by packageId for curated installations.

faq.question: Can I use both packages and collections in the same prpm.json?
faq.answer: Yes. Define packages with files in the packages array and reference them or external packages in collections.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides guidance text. It does not read, write, or transmit any files or data.

faq.question: Why is my manifest failing validation?
faq.answer:: Common issues include missing required fields, duplicate package names, invalid file paths, or wrong tag formatting (must be kebab-case).

faq.question: How does this compare to package.json?
faq.answer: prpm.json is for publishing AI tool packages (skills, rules, agents). package.json is for Node.js dependencies. They serve different purposes.
